security_audit.summary: This is a pure prompt-based skill containing only documentation and IaC patterns for infrastructure deployment. No executable code, network calls, file system access, or external commands are present. The skill behavior matches its stated purpose exactly.

content.user_title: Deploy Guts nodes with IaC patterns
content.value_statement: Deploying decentralized infrastructure requires careful planning across multiple environments. This skill provides ready-to-use Terraform, Docker, and Kubernetes patterns for deploying Guts nodes consistently from local development to production.
actual_capabilities: Create Terraform modules for cloud infrastructure provisioning
Write multi-stage Docker builds for optimized container images
Configure Docker Compose for local multi-node development
Define Kubernetes StatefulSets for production node deployment
Implement monitoring stacks with Prometheus, Loki, and Jaeger
Apply security best practices for TLS, secrets, and RBAC
limitations: Does not execute infrastructure changes directly
Requires existing cloud credentials for Terraform deployments
Does not manage state files or remote state backends
Assumes basic familiarity with Terraform, Docker, and Kubernetes concepts

use_cases.title: Set up multi-node devnet

use_cases.title: Deploy to Kubernetes

prompt_templates.title: Local devnet setup

prompt_templates.title: Production deployment
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a Kubernetes StatefulSet configuration for deploying Guts nodes in production with persistent storage

prompt_templates.title: Terraform module
prompt_templates.prompt: Write a Terraform module structure for deploying Guts nodes on AWS with proper networking

prompt_templates.title: Security hardening
prompt_templates.prompt: What security configurations should I apply to my Guts node deployment including TLS, secrets, and network policies

output_examples.input: Show me a Docker Compose configuration for running a local Guts development network with 3 nodes
output: A three-service Docker Compose file with ports 8081-8083 mapped
Each service configured with unique node ID and peer environment variables
Named volumes for persistent data storage per node
Shared build context for container image compilation

best_practices: Use multi-stage Docker builds to minimize container image size and attack surface
Separate Terraform environments (dev, staging, prod) with isolated state backends
Apply network policies and pod security standards in Kubernetes for isolation
anti_patterns: Avoid hardcoding credentials in Docker or Kubernetes configurations
Do not expose node API ports directly to the public internet without TLS termination
Avoid running containers as root user in production deployments

faq.question: What cloud providers does this skill support?
faq.answer: The skill focusesagnostic patterns. Terraform modules reference on cloud- AWS as an example but can be adapted to any provider.

faq.question: What are the minimum resources needed to run a Guts node?
faq.answer: The skill suggests t3.medium as a default instance type but actual requirements depend on your workload and consensus settings.

faq.question: How do I connect nodes in a multi-node setup?
faq.answer: Configure the GUTS_PEERS environment variable with the hostnames and P2P ports of all peer nodes.

faq.question: Is my data safe when using the example configurations?
faq.answer: The skill provides starting templates. Always apply security hardening including TLS, secrets management, and network policies before production use.

faq.question: Why are my containers failing to start?
faq.answer: Check that ports are not already in use, volumes have proper permissions, and environment variables are correctly configured for your network topology.

faq.question: How does this compare to manual deployment?
faq.answer: IaC provides consistency, repeatability, and version control for infrastructure. Manual deployments are error-prone and difficult to reproduce across environments.
